document.title: Mathematics Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools

6263EAA04403422992E45E96342CCEF0.description:
Transfer a given repeating or increasing pattern from one form to another (e.g., objects,
pictures, numbers) and explain the connection between the two patterns.

6CC3264C02D145DA87B3B83AFC417577.description:
Create a repeating or increasing pattern using various representations (e.g., objects, pictures,
numbers).

6BF54AEC83FA454EAEE441F136FB18F3.description:
Analyze a repeating or increasing pattern and generalize the change to extend the pattern
using objects, pictures, and numbers.

C63F292013334EBC80F6826439F3F7D0.description: Identify and describe repeating and increasing patterns.

B70561F38C554D848E61691823C17EAF.description:
The student will describe, extend, create, and transfer repeating and increasing
patterns (limited to addition of whole numbers) using various representations.

527A1E355A034BC8B68E4FE08D9A47F4.description: draw conclusions about the data and make predictions based on the data.

7AA8A699E8C448C5957FB6764F55A02C.description:
ask and answer questions about the data represented in pictographs and bar graphs (e.g.,
total number of data points represented, how many in each category, how many more or
less are in one category than another). Pictograph keys will be limited to symbols representing 1, 2, 5, or 10 pieces of data and bar graphs will be limited to scales with
increments in multiples of 1, 2, 5, or 10; and

BD50C6E586BE4CD9B543551BD9CB8DD5.description: Analyze data represented in pictographs and bar graphs and communicate results:

0A86F1A17A2D4A18B70830022DB1CEAA.description:
Organize and represent a data set using a bar graph with a title and labeled axes (limited to 25
or fewer data points for up to six categories, and limit increments of scale to multiples of 1 or
2).

7DAF4F2FD65A4E108374DAFBA138B54F.description:
Organize and represent a data set using a pictograph where each symbol represents up to 2
data points. Determine and use a key to assist in the analysis of the data.

518828A4FBDA4533A3239930DE67D003.description:
Determine the data needed to answer a posed question and collect the data using various
methods (e.g., voting; creating lists, tables, or charts; tallying).

889F36C9BDA44831AB1371EFA1A067D6.description:
Pose questions, given a predetermined context, that require the collection of data (limited to
25 or fewer data points for no more than six categories).

9FAF517A1783469B8FC92110FB6303EA.description:
The student will apply the data cycle (pose questions; collect or acquire data; organize
and represent data; and analyze data and communicate results) with a focus on
pictographs and bar graphs.

E72AC61E80FF492991CD144876B7E4E2.description:
Compare and contrast plane and solid figures (circles/spheres, squares/cubes, and
rectangles/rectangular prisms) according to their characteristics (e.g., number and shapes of
their faces, edges, vertices).

CF548BD4A3304B22872C3BF1D718E191.description:
Given a concrete or pictorial model, name and describe the solid figure (sphere, cube, and
rectangular prism) by its characteristics (e.g., number of edges, number of vertices, shapes of
faces).

7FE9815E4D934B3CA48396B262C7268A.description:
Compare and contrast models and nets (cutouts) of cubes and rectangular prisms (e.g.,
number and shapes of faces, edges, vertices).

9006611A6C6548B996B3B391A060D51B.description:
Trace faces of solid figures (cubes and rectangular prisms) to create the set of plane figures
related to the solid figure.

F7B5FCB9B6804B4EA57AB592CE222B56.description:
The student will describe, name, compare, and contrast plane and solid figures
(circles/spheres, squares/cubes, and rectangles/rectangular prisms).

14F15E172A574E3F91EB8781739A2C11.description:
Describe the two resulting figures formed by a line of symmetry as being congruent (having
the same shape and size).

EAFDB4D684ED42DFA36DE3DAC036926E.description:
Create figures with at least one line of symmetry using various concrete and pictorial
representations.

BF2FC06D4E8547969F5621076912F95D.description:
Explore a figure using a variety of tools (e.g., paper folding, geoboards, drawings) to show
and justify a line of symmetry, if one exists.

54B6A6A2F3044E3F9CC1B5488CCA9EEA.description:
The student will identify, describe, and create plane figures (including circles,
triangles, squares, and rectangles) that have at least one line of symmetry and explain
its relationship with congruency.

B2EFE351031F4344A7939806236F4CB8.description:
Match a written time (e.g., 1:35, 6:20, 9:05) to the time shown on an analog clock to the
nearest five minutes.

4FBA9DEDC9224EA994A74A97DE1EBFD2.description: Show, tell, and write time to the nearest five minutes, using analog and digital clocks.

7B33D6C87B3745DD827DE5CE658D9614.description:
Determine the unit of time (minutes, hours, days, or weeks) that is most appropriate when
measuring a given activity or context and explain reasoning (e.g., Would you measure the
time it takes to brush your teeth in minutes or hours?).

16D0B44AC86A45A0818A52CAE8FFC21C.description:
Identify the number of minutes in an hour (60 minutes) and the number of hours in a day (24
hours).

F0756A600DED48E888944D97BA138D6D.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the concept of time to the nearest
five minutes, using analog and digital clocks.

AC6717EC5BD34D69BA540A5F8237A3C4.description: the liquid volume of a container to the nearest cup, using a measuring cup.

7AB3ADF990934798BAB710DED2E8DCF6.description: the weight of an object to the nearest pound, using a scale; and

F2CE2EA752FE4FF2A07BF7975A62F73D.description: the length of an object to the nearest inch, using a ruler;

D2DEFBC223344549BF25594648CF77B6.description: Use U.S. Customary units to estimate, measure, and compare the two for reasonableness:

E15B2D97959D4DE4A71AC99644A0B022.description: identifying different types of measuring cups as instruments to measure liquid volume.

49E5598E41194A2499D952CAD53733A3.description: identifying different types of scales as instruments to measure weight; and

D4E8F8D7FD75448BB291E20D3BCCC3DE.description: identifying a ruler as an instrument to measure length;

09377AE311064014BC9BE70D69254D86.description: Explain the purpose of various measurement tools and how to use them appropriately by:

56C615A85E44420BB17F56D89E6C56E0.description:
The student will reason mathematically using standard units (U.S. Customary) with
appropriate tools to estimate, measure, and compare objects by length, weight, and
liquid volume to the nearest whole unit.

62BB5A0C452E4BA092A96DD24D1735D1.description:
Represent and justify the relationship between values and expressions as equal or not equal
using appropriate models and/or symbols (e.g., 9 + 24 = 10 + 23; 45 - 9 = 46 - 10; 15 +16 ≠
31 +15).

528C7F37282E4A01AEC9D11D0AC9424D.description:
Describe the not equal symbol (≠) as representing a relationship where expressions on either
side of the not equal symbol represent different values and justify reasoning.

E55E56AF07054108804CCF94446BF16E.description:
Use inverse relationships to write all related facts connected to a given addition or subtraction
fact model within 20 (e.g., given a model for 3 + 4 = 7, write 4 + 3 = 7, 7 – 4 = 3, and 7 – 3 =
4).

A2876AD927F34171917D09E8ECC90015.description:
Determine the missing number in an equation (number sentence) through modeling and
justification with addition and subtraction within 20 (e.g., 3 + = 5 or + 2 = 5; 5 – = 3
or 5 – 2 = ).

40B795ED58BC4121BFCC2FDF581F21E6.description:
Use patterns, models, and strategies to make generalizations about the algebraic properties for
fluency (e.g., 4 + 3 is equal to 3 + 4; 0 + 8 = 8).

6A608C8B008248FE87D432BCC38EA79F.description: Recall with automaticity addition and subtraction facts within 20.

3DA8CE5C7C164263BBB7C64F8B83491B.description:
Demonstrate fluency with addition and subtraction within 20 by applying reasoning strategies
(e.g., doubles, near doubles, make-a-ten, compensations, inverse relationships).

CE0F33C4BE8D4D82BC1E8A1DA573557B.description:
Represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step and multistep contextual problems (e.g.,
join, separate, part-part-whole, comparison) involving addition or subtraction of whole
numbers where addends or minuends do not exceed 100.

AB0AA057AA92478B9C97486FF8622E69.description:
Apply strategies (e.g., the use of concrete and pictorial models, place value, properties of
addition, the relationship between addition and subtraction) to determine the sum or
difference of two whole numbers where addends or minuends do not exceed 100.

BFAB9F29EA264F8EB44295766431960E.description:
Apply strategies (e.g., rounding to the nearest 10, compatible numbers, other number
relationships) to estimate a solution for single-step addition or subtraction problems, including
those in context, where addends and minuends do not exceed 100.

65224BD3A8D04569B07F52ABDA531D40.description:
The student will recall with automaticity addition and subtraction facts within 20 and
estimate, represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step and multistep problems,
including those in context, using addition and subtraction with whole numbers where
addends or minuends do not exceed 100.

6F1B6C1DB135415F8A1170BC7245E0FA.description:
Represent the value of a collection of coins and one-dollar bills (limited to $2.00 or less)
using the cent (¢) and dollar ($) symbols and decimal point (.).

9874E521A74D45ECB972B7233C57B3F6.description:
Construct a set of coins and/or bills to total a given amount of money whose value is $2.00 or
less.

4D12FD367BBF471BB563A6EEBFA11258.description:
Count by ones, fives, tens, and twenty-fives to determine the value of a collection of mixed
coins and one-dollar bills whose total value is $2.00 or less.

3256ECCF53F445D3966786AB44D595CA.description:
Identify a quarter and its value and determine multiple ways to represent the value of a quarter
using pennies, nickels, and/or dimes.

86187655175E4E0D846B3638A913F465.description:
The student will solve problems that involve counting and representing money amounts
up to $2.00.

A743F903C66449D9A7039BA43B34F155.description:
Compare unit fractions for halves, fourths, eighths, thirds, and sixths using words (greater
than, less than or equal to) and symbols (>, <, =), with region/area and length models.

C7AB5789C4FD4F41824FE05FCD8B5D44.description: length models (e.g., paper fraction strips, fraction bars, rods, number lines); and

5B0D26AD30BB45BEA4D379DF23ED217A.description: region/area models (e.g., pie pieces, pattern blocks, geoboards);

791CB056342C4E1E91554CE6475F8752.description:
Given a context, represent, name, and write fractional parts of a whole for halves, fourths,
eighths, thirds, and sixths using:

1939549DADE542FE91F3E9F44803AA61.description:
Using same-size fraction pieces, from a region/area model, count by unit fractions up to two
wholes (e.g., zero one-fourths, one one-fourth, two one-fourths, three one-fourths, four onefourths, five one-fourths; or zero-fourths, one-fourth, two-fourths, three-fourths, four-fourths,
five-fourths).

C68106DD51C44F2099AD848708A3C6A9.description:
Compose the whole for a given fractional part and its value (in context) for halves, fourths,
eighths, thirds, and sixths (e.g., when given 1
4
, determine how many pieces would be needed to
make 4
4
).

7AA9853351F44CA2AFA636357E1A3802.description:
Describe the relationship between the number of fractional parts needed to make a whole and
the size of the parts (i.e., as the whole is divided into more parts, each part becomes smaller).

84247699694E4E67BDAEB6AEA2F34590.description: Model and describe fractions as representing equal-size parts of a whole.

F8BAB84B28E6480A937A732B2BDAC532.description:
The student will use mathematical reasoning and justification to solve contextual
problems that involve partitioning models into equal-sized parts (halves, fourths,
eighths, thirds, and sixths).

03C4FA92D672499C9424CB0C55844304.description:
Order up to three whole numbers, each 999 or less, represented concretely, pictorially, or
symbolically from least to greatest and greatest to least.

5D0248ABCE9541DFB9106979F5211325.description:
Compare two whole numbers, each 999 or less, represented concretely, pictorially, or
symbolically, using words (greater than, less than, or equal to) and symbols (>, <, or =).
Justify reasoning orally, in writing, or with a model.

27829C45D80E4F97B8CC7F90FA4647D9.description:
Plot and justify the position of a given number up to 100 on a number line with pre-marked
benchmarks of 1s, 2s, 5s, 10s, or 25s.

FDC34005FF8D43B283CF10C40B442AA6.description:
Compose and decompose whole numbers up to 200 by making connections between a variety
of models (e.g., base 10 blocks, place value cards, presented orally, in expanded or standard
form) and counting strategies (e.g., 156 can be 1 hundred, 5 tens, 6 ones; 1 hundred, 4 tens, 16
ones; 15 tens, 6 ones).

5BF5F29D768C4F0A87D4C339EBC39C4E.description:
Investigate and explain the ten-to-one relationships among ones, tens, and hundreds, using
models.

3BAA07CE67864065A77CE0804224BB1A.description:
Apply patterns within the base 10 system to determine and communicate, orally and in written
form, the place (ones, tens, hundreds) and value of each digit in a three-digit whole number
(e.g., in 352, the 5 represents 5 tens and its value is 50).

D763185AB7474714889DD81DF477F605.description:
Read, write, and represent three-digit numbers in standard form, expanded form, and word
form, using concrete or pictorial representations.

7FA30AB9599E40288EB9C2E96ED1D8B3.description:
Write the three-digit whole number represented by a given model (e.g., concrete objects,
pictures of base 10 blocks).

85B48BEEB5ED46019715857FE9DD4297.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the ten-to-one relationships of the
base 10 number system to represent, compare, and order whole numbers up to 999.

E1D40835427741B2913243CBF134CD49.description:
Determine whether a number (up to 50) is even or odd using concrete objects and justify
reasoning (e.g., dividing collections of objects into two equal groups, pairing objects).

7467185BD2C94C3FAFE569EB707DD4C3.description:
Represent odd numbers (up to 50) with concrete objects, using two equal groups with one
leftover or two equal addends plus 1.

A131A04AD73647449A1F85166103235B.description:
Represent even numbers (up to 50) with concrete objects, using two equal groups or two
equal addends.

0C1069924A3141709137190CDF0EDEAB.description:
Choose a reasonable estimate up to 1,000 when given a contextual problem (e.g., What would
be the best estimate for the number of students in our school – 5, 50, or 500?).

9394E20E7D2F44DCA52C9674926DB066.description:
Describe and use patterns in skip counting backwards by 10s (from at least 200) to justify the
next number in the counting sequence.

C491009520A54FD2A26F1DD41D183DBA.description:
Represent backward counting patterns when counting by groups of 10 from 200 or less using
a variety of tools including objects, number lines, calculators, and hundreds charts.

3F13D780514645F2AB4CBD8BD0858742.description:
Represent forward counting patterns when counting by groups of 100 up to at least 1,000
starting at 0 using a variety of tools (e.g., objects, number lines, calculators, one thousand
charts).

2FF57CEEEC964B978FD9EBF476CAA39F.description:
Describe and use patterns in skip counting by multiples of 2 (to at least 50), and multiples of
5, 10, and 25 (to at least 200) to justify the next number in the counting sequence.

6314DB53C55D4143BDF6B26C8141E686.description:
Represent forward counting patterns created when counting by groups of 5s, 10s, and 25s
starting at various multiples up to at least 200 using a variety of tools (e.g., objects, number
lines, hundreds charts).

6C4DE6111C5C4CDB985C48B288E625E7.description:
Represent forward counting patterns when counting by groups of 2 up to at least 50, starting
at various multiples of 2 and using a variety of tools (e.g., objects, number lines, hundreds
charts).

E610C6861000439A9C0CF569D96F41F9.description:
The student will utilize flexible counting strategies to determine and describe quantities
up to 200.
